Course_Name: [SoSe 2024] Selected advanced topics in development, environmental and public economics

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, our course is coming to an end. Next week, we will have our final session which is reserved for your presentations. Each presentation should inform about your seminar paper. It would be interesting to learn about the motivation for your paper, your research question, the kind of answer you are looking for and possibly what kind of method you are likely to apply. You may also point to next steps or bring questions to which you would like to receive answers. Ideally, each presentation should not take more than five minutes, such that there is sufficient time for questions and comments. Therefore, we recommend to limit your presentation to three slides. As announced, please feel warmly invited to join us for some ice cream after the course. Do not hesitate to get in touch in case of any questions. My e-mail is missbach@mcc-berlin.net. All the best Leonard

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Next week: Presentation by Farah Mohammadzadeh Valencia

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, next week, there will be a presentation by Farah Mohammadzadeh Valencia. She has an excellent overview about public support for carbon pricing policies and revenue recycling options.  As a preparation, I would ask you to read her manuscript "Public support for carbon pricing policies and revenue recycling options: a systematic review and meta-analysis of the survey literature" that I have uploaded here on ISIS. In particular, it would be great if you could pay extra attention to the "Methods" and "Discussion" section of this paper. Please feel invited to collect any questions and comments that you may have. As usual, we will start at 4 pm. Do not hesitate to get in touch in any of any questions (and consider sending your outline for feedback). All the best Leonard

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, time is running fast and there will be only four joint seminar sessions left for this semester. By July 15, all of you should be clear about your research question, about the next steps in your research and writing process, as well as about our expectations about your seminar paper. Therefore, I would like to encourage everybody to make the best use of the time in our seminar dedicated to feedback and discussions. Please consider advancing your outline over the week and do not hesitate to send something through e-mail well before Monday. This would really facilitate preparation. On Monday, there will be some time to work on your seminar paper, to exchange and receive feedback. On first of July, we will have Farah with us who will give a guest lecture about public acceptance and climate policy. On July 8, we will talk about academic writing and listen to the first of your short presentations. On July 15, we would like to have most of you presenting. Please also consider having a look at the data science exercise that has been uploaded here on ISIS as well as on the next course on Datacamp. Also, do not hesitate to get in touch in case of any questions or concerns. All the best Leonard

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, thank you once again for attending yesterday's session and for great participation! Until next week, please overhaul your short essay on a research question around the issue of climate policy, distributional impacts and inequality. Importantly, please try to come up with a motivating/positioning statement as discussed yesterday. Please send both in one document to me through e-mail (missbach@mcc-berlin.net), ideally by Thursday, 6th of June. This gives us sufficient time to review your ideas and to prepare for next Monday. Moreover, I have uploaded some data on ISIS on households in Colombia. Download the corresponding R-script Exercise_Colombia.R and try to complete the different tasks. Do not hesitate to get in touch in case of any questions or consult the internet, if some code outcome seems not quite right. There is another course in datacamp which you might find helpful (Data Visualization with ggplot2). Please consider having a look at it. Most importantly, there is an opportunity to provide feedback on the course through ISIS. We would be happy to learn more about what you like about the course and about what could be improved. Any suggestions are welcome and submissions are anonymous. Of course, we are also happy to receive your feedback directly in class. Thank you and all the best Leonard

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, I hope this message finds you well. Before our next session on Monday, June 3rd, I would like to remind you to think carefully about at least one important question around the issue of climate policy, distributional impacts and inequality. You may of course draw on our discussions during the past weeks. If you have not done so already, I would appreciate it if you could send me your thoughts through e-mail (missbach@mcc-berlin.net) by late Sunday. I would encourage you to take some time for this exercise, because we will build on your ideas next Monday. In addition, this is an excellent first step towards finding a topic for your seminar paper. Do not hesitate to contact me in case of any questions or concerns. All the best Leonard

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, thank you once again for attending the session on Monday. Please note that our next session will take place on 27th of May because of the pentecost holiday on 20th of May. Note that we will have Charlotte Bez with us who will provide some insights into her exciting research. Consider visiting her website in advance. As discussed, please do not forget to complete both courses (Introduction R and Introduction to the tidyverse) on Datacamp. Starting in June, we will spend more time with exploring and investigating data, also in class. Having completed such courses will be helpful for that. In addition, please read the paper "Perceived fairness and public acceptability of carbon pricing: a review of the literature". As usual, please take notes on any point that requires clarification or that sparks your interest. Please write a short text about "What appears to be an important question around the issues of climate policy, distributional impacts and inequality?". This text should contain some arguments on your personal perception about interesting research topics. In any case, please get in touch in case of any questions or concerns (missbach@mcc-berlin.net).  Thank you and all the best Leonard

Messages.Author: Linus Mattauch
Messages.Content: Hello students in "Selected Advanced Topics", this year the TU admin convinced me that we should formally do an MTS registration. If you could register your intention to write the seminar paper in this module, please register here by May 30 https://moseskonto.tu-berlin.de/moses/modultransfersystem/modulpruefung/instanz.html?modulpruefungsinstanz=11023 You can "de-register" until mid-August if you change your mind. Thanks for doing it! Best wishes Linus

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, thank you once again for attending yesterday's session. Until next week, please start with the course "Introduction to the tidyverse" on Datacamp. I believe that you will be able to solve 95% of all tasks in R with functions from the tidyverse-package, so it is definetly worth to engage with it. In addition, please read Franziska's paper on meat taxes and associated distributional consequences that I have uploaded on ISIS. Note that from now on the seminar will start at 4 pm s.t., as we have agreed last week. Do not hesitate to get in touch in case of any questions or concerns (missbach@mcc-berlin.net). All the best Leonard

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, thank you once again for attending this week's session on Monday. Please do not forget to register on datacamp. You find a link here on ISIS. Please get in touch in case of any difficulties. Install R and RStudio. You find an instruction here on ISIS. Read the suggested paper on climate policy and carbon pricing. Write a short essay about who should bear the costs of climate policy. Please send it either through ISIS where you find a dedicated field for submission or send it through e-mail to missbach@mcc-berlin.net. I can really encourage you to see this as an opportunity to improve your writing skills. Essays will not be graded, but I will make sure to provide some short feedback. Let me know in case of any questions. I look very much forward to next week's session on Monday, 6th of April - 4 pm (c.t.) in FH 303.  In case you have not yet sent an e-mail to indicate interest in participation in this course, please do so.  All the best Leonard

Messages.Author: Leonard Damian Missbach
Messages.Content: Dear all, thank you very much for your interest in this course and your participation in yesterday's first session. Unfortunately, I was unable to join, but I look very much forward to meeting you in person next week. It is important to note that this course has a limited capacity of 15 participants. If you are interested in participating, please do not forget to indicate your interest by sending an e-mail to missbach@mcc-berlin.net by Thursday, April 18. Thanks to all of you who have already sent an e-mail - I will get back to you by the end of the week. I wish you a great start into the new semester. All the best Leonard
